summary: This document is an email chain from October 30, 2019, between U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS) and the Office of the Deputy Attorney General (ODAG) staff. It discusses the logistics and outcomes of victim impact statements for the Jeffrey Epstein case, specifically regarding a hearing in SDNY. The emails detail efforts to contact victims, provide travel arrangements, and report on how many victims attended or submitted statements, in response to an appeal challenging whether all victims had sufficient opportunity to be heard.

events.title: SDNY Victim Impact Statement Hearing
events.description: A hearing held in the Southern District of New York where Epstein victims were given the opportunity to make impact statements. The document reports 17 victims were present and spoke or had statements read, and 7 additional victims had statements read on their behalf without attending.

events.title: ODAG Inquiry Regarding Victim Access
events.description: The Office of the Deputy Attorney General sends an urgent request to the USANYS for details on victim contact and access to the impact statement hearing, due to an appeal filed by the petitioner in the Epstein CVRA case challenging whether all victims had sufficient notice and ability to participate.

keyFacts: The U.S. Attorney's Office had a victim contact list (VNS) containing 39 victims they were in touch with regarding the impact statement hearing.
At the SDNY hearing, 17 victims were present and spoke or had statements read, and an additional 7 victims had statements read for them without attending.

The prosecution communicated with attorneys Brad Edwards, Robert Josefsberg, Robbie Kaplan, and Boies Schiller, who collectively represented multiple victim clients, some of whom remained anonymous to the prosecution.
One victim, represented by either Brad Edwards or Singrid McCally, missed two arranged flights to attend the hearing and was a no-show.

The Office of the Deputy Attorney General requested this information to respond to an appeal arguing that not all Epstein victims who wanted to speak were able to do so due to insufficient notice and travel difficulties.
